CONJUGATES: competence (n) | competently (adv) | more competent | most competent
ETYMOLOGY: From Latin competentem (present participle of competere 'to meet, agree, be suitable'). The sense of 'properly qualified' developed in Late Middle English.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Adjective: a word or phrase naming an attribute, added to a noun to modify or describe it
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully or efficiently.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 有能力的；能干的；胜任的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The new manager is extremely competent and handles pressure well.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这位新经理非常能干，并且能很好地处理压力。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Adjective: a word or phrase naming an attribute, added to a noun to modify or describe it
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Legally authorized or qualified to decide a matter or perform an official function; having jurisdiction.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: (法律) 有法定权限的；有管辖权的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Only a competent judicial authority can review this case.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 只有具备管辖权的司法机构才能审理此案。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: Adjective: a word or phrase naming an attribute, added to a noun to modify or describe it
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Adequate but not exceptional; acceptable or satisfactory.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 尚可的；过得去的（指达到标准但非杰出的）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The concert offered a competent but uninspired rendition of the classical piece.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这场音乐会对古典作品的演绎还算过得去，但缺乏灵感。
